page.title: 01INTRODUCTION: LANDSCAPE
page.content: The 12 square kilometres of our study is a rural area to the west of the ancient Scottish town of Dunfermline. It is an undulating area of countryside, sloping overall from a high point of 70 metres in the north down to the Firth of Forth in the south. The bedrock of mainly limestone and sandstone is overlain by a thick layer of boulder clay, and this clay is ideal for the arable farming which dominates the area. Barley is the most common crop in 1985, but potatoes, wheat, and many fields of oil-seed rape were also seen. The rural nature of the area is gradually being altered by the growth of the villages of Cairneyhill and Crossford, with many large housing estates being built in the past few years. Crombie village is, however, somewhat in decline.
